title: Phishing
content: A deceptive technique used to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information.

title: Ransomware
content: Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for the decryption key.

title: Red Team
content: A group that simulates attacks to test an organization's defenses.

title: Blue Team
content: The internal security team responsible for defending against cyber threats.

title: Black Hat
content: Hackers who violate computer security for personal gain or malice.

title: White Hat
content: Ethical hackers who use their skills to improve security systems.

title: Grey Hat
content: Hackers who may violate laws but usually without malicious intent.

title: Zero-Day Exploit
content: An attack that targets a software vulnerability unknown to the vendor.

title: SQL Injection
content: A vulnerability where attackers insert malicious SQL code into entry fields.

title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
content: Injecting malicious scripts into benign and trusted websites.

title: Brute Force Attack
content: Trial-and-error method used to guess passwords or encryption keys.

title: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)
content: An attack where the attacker secretly intercepts communications.

title: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS)
content: Flooding a target with traffic to crash its servers or network.

title: Firewall
content: A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing traffic.

title: Encryption
content: The process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access.

title: Social Engineering
content: The psychological manipulation of people into performing actions or divulging info.

title: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
content: A security system requiring more than one method of authentication.

title: Penetration Testing
content: A simulated cyberattack against your computer system to check for vulnerabilities.

title: Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
content: A device or software application that monitors a network for malicious activity.

title: Endpoint Security
content: The practice of securing endpoints or entry points of end-user devices.

title: Cryptography
content: The practice and study of techniques for secure communication.

title: Keylogger
content: A type of surveillance software that records every keystroke made on a keyboard.

title: Malware
content: Software specifically designed to disrupt damage or gain unauthorized access.

title: Spyware
content: Software that enables a user to obtain covert information about another's computer activities.

title: Trojan Horse
content: A program that appears harmless but is actually malicious.

title: Computer Worm
content: A self-replicating malware program that spreads through computer networks.

title: Data Breach
content: The intentional or unintentional release of secure or private information.

title: Virtual Private Network (VPN)
content: A service that creates a safe encrypted connection over a less secure network.

title: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
content: A framework for managing digital certificates and public-key encryption.

title: Digital Signature
content: A mathematical scheme for verifying the authenticity of digital messages.

title: Security Operations Center (SOC)
content: A centralized unit that deals with security issues on an organizational level.

title: Incident Response
content: The process by which an organization handles a data breach or cyberattack.

title: Risk Management
content: The process of identifying monitoring and managing potential security risks.

title: Vulnerability Assessment
content: The process of defining identifying and prioritizing vulnerabilities in a system.

title: Asset Management
content: The practice of tracking and managing an organization's IT assets.

title: Network Segmentation
content: The practice of splitting a network into smaller sub-networks.

title: Least Privilege Principle
content: The practice of limiting access rights for users to the bare minimum.

title: Bio-metric Authentication
content: Security processes that use unique biological traits to identify individuals.

title: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
content: A framework of policies for ensuring proper people have access to technology.

title: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
content: A standard security technology for establishing an encrypted link.

title: Transport Layer Security (TLS)
content: The successor to SSL providing more secure communication.

title: Honeypot
content: A decoy system used to lure and study potential hackers.

title: Threat Intelligence
content: Information used by an organization to understand the threats it faces.

title: Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)
content: A prolonged and targeted cyberattack by a high-level attacker.

title: Sandboxing
content: A security mechanism for separating running programs from the underlying system.

title: Patch Management
content: The process of managing a network of computers by deploying software updates.

title: Antivirus Software
content: A program used to prevent detect and remove malware.

title: Cloud Security
content: A broad set of control technologies used to protect cloud computing environments.

title: Dark Web
content: A part of the internet that is intentionally hidden and requires specific software to access.

title: Packet Sniffing
content: The process of capturing and analyzing data packets as they flow across a network.

title: Buffer Overflow
content: An anomaly where a program writes data beyond the boundary of a buffer.

title: Rootkit
content: A collection of software tools that enable an unauthorized user to gain control.

title: Script Kiddie
content: An unskilled individual who uses scripts or programs developed by others to attack.

title: Cyber Espionage
content: The act or practice of obtaining secrets without permission via the internet.

title: Air Gapping
content: A security measure that ensures a computer or network is physically isolated.

title: Logic Bomb
content: A piece of code intentionally inserted into a software system that sets off a malicious function.

title: Privilege Escalation
content: The act of exploiting a bug or design flaw to gain elevated access.

title: Backdoor
content: A method of bypassing normal authentication in a cryptosystem or algorithm.

title: Dictionary Attack
content: A method of breaking into a password-protected computer by entering every word in a dictionary.

title: Exfiltration
content: The unauthorized transfer of data from a computer.

title: Fuzzing
content: An automated software testing technique that involves providing semi-random data as input.

title: Hardening
content: The process of securing a system by reducing its surface of vulnerability.

title: Payload
content: The part of transmitted data that is the actual intended message or malicious code.

title: Reverse Engineering
content: The process of analyzing a system to identify its components and their interrelationships.

title: Salting
content: Adding random data to a password before hashing it to protect against pre-computed attacks.

title: Threat Hunting
content: The process of proactively searching through networks to detect and isolate threats.

title: Whaling
content: A highly targeted phishing attack aimed at high-ranking executives.

title: Zombie
content: A computer connected to the internet that has been compromised by a hacker via a virus.

title: Zero Trust
content: A security model that requires strict identity verification for every person and device.

title: Container Security
content: The tools and policies used to protect containerized applications.

title: Digital Forensics
content: The branch of forensic science encompassing the recovery and investigation of material found in digital devices.

title: Exploit Kit
content: A software kit designed to run on web servers with the purpose of identifying vulnerabilities.

title: Information Security (InfoSec)
content: The practice of protecting information by mitigating information risks.

title: Interoperability
content: The ability of computer systems or software to exchange and make use of information.

title: Kernel
content: The core of a computer's operating system with complete control over everything in the system.

title: Macro Virus
content: A virus that is written in a macro language and embedded into documents.

title: Network Traffic Analysis (NTA)
content: The process of recording reviewing and analyzing network traffic patterns.

title: Open Source Intelligence (OSINT)
content: The collection and analysis of data gathered from open sources.

title: Passive Attack
content: An attack where the attacker does not interact with the target system.

title: Active Attack
content: An attack where the attacker attempts to alter system resources or affect their operation.

title: Quantum Cryptography
content: The science of exploiting quantum mechanical properties to perform cryptographic tasks.

title: Remote Access Trojan (RAT)
content: A malware program that includes a back door for administrative control.

title: Secure Boot
content: A security standard developed by members of the PC industry to help ensure a device boots using only trusted software.

title: Security Token
content: A peripheral device used to gain access to an electronically restricted resource.

title: Steganography
content: The practice of concealing a file message image or video within another file.

title: Tailgating
content: A physical security breach where an unauthorized person follows an authorized person into a secure area.

title: UDP Flood
content: A type of denial-of-service attack using User Datagram Protocol packets.

title: Vault
content: A secure digital storage for sensitive keys passwords and certificates.

title: War Driving
content: The act of searching for Wi-Fi wireless networks by a person in a moving vehicle.

title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
content: An attack that forces an authenticated user to execute unwanted actions on a web app.

title: Drip Feed Phishing
content: A slow-paced phishing attack designed to evade detection by security software.

title: Ethernet Security
content: Security protocols used to protect data transmitted over an Ethernet network.

title: Firmware Attack
content: A cyberattack that targets the software programmed into a hardware device's memory.

title: Guidance Software
content: Tools used for digital investigations and incident response.

title: Hash Function
content: A function that converts an input into a fixed-size string of characters.

title: Incident Management
content: The activities of an organization to identify analyze and correct hazards.

title: Juice Jacking
content: A type of cyberattack involving a charging port that doubles as a data connection.

title: Kill Chain
content: A model used to describe the stages of a cyberattack.

title: Local File Inclusion (LFI)
content: An exploit where an attacker tricks a web application into exposing or running files on the server.

title: Managed Security Service Provider (MSSP)
content: A service provider that provides outsourced monitoring and management of security systems.

title: Non-Repudiation
content: The assurance that someone cannot deny the validity of something.

title: Purple Team
content: A collaborative group that integrates Red and Blue team tactics for better security.

title: Social Media Hijacking
content: The process of gaining unauthorized access to social media accounts.

title: Adware
content: Software that automatically displays or downloads advertising material.

title: Clickjacking
content: A technique of tricking a user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives.

title: Vishing
content: The fraudulent practice of making phone calls to trick people into giving personal information.

title: Smishing
content: Phishing conducted via SMS text messages.

title: Watering Hole Attack
content: An attack where the attacker infects a website frequently visited by a specific group.

title: Typosquatting
content: Registering domain names that are misspellings of popular websites.

title: Shoulder Surfing
content: Direct observation techniques such as looking over someone's shoulder to get passwords.

title: Dumpster Diving
content: Searching through trash to find information that could be used in a cyberattack.

title: Eavesdropping
content: The act of secretly listening to a private conversation or communication.

title: Pretexting
content: A form of social engineering where an attacker creates a fabricated scenario to steal info.

title: Scareware
content: Malicious software that tricks users into believing their computer has a virus.

title: Rogue Access Point
content: A wireless access point installed on a network without authorization.

title: Evil Twin
content: A fraudulent Wi-Fi access point that appears to be legitimate.

title: Bluejacking
content: The sending of unsolicited messages over Bluetooth to Bluetooth-enabled devices.

title: Bluesnarfing
content: The unauthorized access of information from a wireless device through a Bluetooth connection.

title: Side-Channel Attack
content: An attack based on information gained from the physical implementation of a system.

title: Cold Boot Attack
content: A type of side-channel attack where an attacker retrieves encryption keys from RAM.

title: Denial of Service (DoS)
content: An attack meant to shut down a machine or network making it inaccessible.

title: Ping of Death
content: A type of DoS attack in which the attacker sends a fragmented or malformed packet.

title: Smurf Attack
content: A DDoS attack in which large numbers of ICMP packets with the victim's spoofed source IP are sent.

title: Fraggle Attack
content: A type of DoS attack that uses a large amount of spoofed UDP traffic to a network.

title: SYN Flood
content: A type of DoS attack in which an attacker sends a succession of SYN requests to a system.

title: Teardrop Attack
content: A DoS attack that involves sending fragmented packets to a target machine.

title: Zero-Knowledge Proof
content: A method by which one party can prove to another that they know a value without revealing it.

title: CAPTCHA
content: A type of challenge-response test used in computing to determine whether the user is human.

title: Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)
content: A subset of MFA requiring exactly two forms of identification.

title: Bastion Host
content: A special-purpose computer on a network specifically designed to withstand attacks.

title: Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
content: A physical or logical subnetwork that contains an organization's external-facing services.

title: Stateful Inspection
content: A firewall technology that monitors the state of active connections.

title: Proxy Server
content: A server that acts as an intermediary for requests from clients seeking resources.

title: Airborne Virus
content: A virus that can spread through wireless connections.

title: Logic Bomb
content: A piece of code that will set off a malicious function when specified conditions are met.

title: Polymorphic Malware
content: Malware that constantly changes its identifiable features to evade detection.

title: Metamorphic Malware
content: Malware that rewrites its own code and changes its appearance with each infection.

title: Click Fraud
content: A type of fraud that occurs in pay-per-click online advertising.

title: Botnet
content: A number of Internet-connected devices each of which is running one or more bots.

title: Command and Control (C2)
content: The infrastructure used by attackers to maintain communication with compromised systems.

title: DNS Spoofing
content: A type of attack that exploits vulnerabilities in the Domain Name System.

title: IP Spoofing
content: The creation of IP packets with a false source IP address for impersonation.

title: ARP Spoofing
content: A technique by which an attacker sends spoofed Address Resolution Protocol messages.

title: Session Hijacking
content: The exploitation of a valid computer session to gain unauthorized access.

title: Cookie Poisoning
content: The modification of a cookie to bypass security or steal information.

title: Directory Traversal
content: An HTTP attack which allows attackers to access restricted directories.

title: SQLi
content: Acronym for SQL Injection.

title: Blind SQL Injection
content: A type of SQLi attack that asks the database true or false questions.

title: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)
content: A vulnerability where an application provides direct access to objects based on user-provided input.

title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
content: An attack that tricks a victim into submitting a malicious request.

title: Broken Authentication
content: A vulnerability that allows an attacker to compromise passwords or session tokens.

title: Security Misconfiguration
content: The result of incomplete or ad hoc configuration of security controls.

title: Sensitive Data Exposure
content: The failure to adequately protect sensitive information like financial data.

title: XML External Entity (XXE)
content: An attack against an application that parses XML input.

title: Insecure Deserialization
content: When untrusted data is used to abuse the logic of an application.

title: Using Components with Known Vulnerabilities
content: Using outdated or unpatched software libraries.

title: Insufficient Logging and Monitoring
content: The failure to record security-critical events.

title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
content: A vulnerability where an attacker can force a server-side application to make HTTP requests.

title: Open Redirect
content: A vulnerability where an application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site.

title: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
content: A type of scam targeting companies who conduct wire transfers.

title: CEO Fraud
content: A type of BEC where the attacker poses as a high-ranking executive.

title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP)
content: A strategy for making sure that end users do not send sensitive info outside the corporate network.

title: Security Awareness Training
content: An educational program for employees about cybersecurity risks.

title: Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
content: The senior-level executive responsible for an organization's info security.

title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
content: US legislation that provides data privacy and security provisions for medical info.

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
content: A regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy.

title: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS)
content: A set of security standards designed to ensure that all companies accept credit card info securely.

title: ISO/IEC 27001
content: An international standard on how to manage information security.

title: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
content: A set of guidelines for mitigating organizational cybersecurity risks.

title: Cyber Insurance
content: A specialty insurance product intended to protect businesses from Internet-based risks.

title: Bug Bounty
content: A program where individuals can receive recognition and compensation for reporting bugs.

title: Vulnerability Disclosure Policy (VDP)
content: A policy that outlines how researchers should report security flaws.

title: Responsible Disclosure
content: A process where a vulnerability is disclosed to the vendor before being made public.

title: Full Disclosure
content: The practice of making details of security vulnerabilities public immediately.

title: Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA)
content: A strategic initiative that helps prevent data breaches by eliminating the concept of trust.

title: Micro-segmentation
content: A security technique that enables security policies to be granularly defined around workloads.

title: Software-Defined Perimeter (SDP)
content: A way to hide Internet-connected infrastructure from external parties.

title: Identity Provider (IdP)
content: A system entity that creates maintains and manages identity information.

title: Service Provider (SP)
content: An entity that provides web services to users.

title: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)
content: An open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data.

title: OAuth
content: An open standard for access delegation commonly used for token-based authentication.

title: OpenID Connect (OIDC)
content: An identity layer on top of the OAuth 2.0 protocol.

title: JSON Web Token (JWT)
content: An open standard that defines a compact and self-contained way for securely transmitting info.

title: Brute Force
content: Attempting all possible password combinations until the correct one is found.

title: Rainbow Table
content: A precomputed table for reversing cryptographic hash functions.

title: Pass-the-Hash
content: A hacking technique that allows an attacker to authenticate to a remote server using a password hash.

title: Credential Stuffing
content: The automated injection of stolen username and password pairs into website login forms.

title: Brute-forcing
content: The act of using automated software to generate a large number of consecutive guesses.

title: Dictionary Attack
content: A method of breaking a password by trying all the words in a pre-arranged list.

title: Exploit
content: A piece of software or data that takes advantage of a bug or vulnerability.

title: Payload
content: The part of the exploit that performs the malicious action.

title: Shellcode
content: A small piece of code used as the payload in the exploitation of a software vulnerability.

title: Reverse Shell
content: A type of shell in which the target machine communicates back to the attacking machine.

title: Bind Shell
content: A type of shell where the attacker connects to a specific port on the target machine.

title: Meterpreter
content: An advanced extensible payload that uses in-memory DLL injection.

title: Cobalt Strike
content: A commercial penetration testing tool that provides a post-exploitation agent.

title: Metasploit
content: A computer security project that provides information about security vulnerabilities.

title: Nmap
content: A free and open-source network scanner.

title: Wireshark
content: A free and open-source packet analyzer.

title: Burp Suite
content: A graphical tool for testing Web application security.

title: John the Ripper
content: A free password cracking software tool.

title: Hashcat
content: A powerful and fast password recovery tool.

title: Hydra
content: A parallelized login cracker which supports numerous protocols.

title: Aircrack-ng
content: A network software suite consisting of a detector packet sniffer and cracker for wireless LANs.

title: Mimikatz
content: An open-source tool that allows users to view and save authentication credentials.

title: BloodHound
content: A tool used to reveal the hidden and often unintended relationships within an Active Directory environment.

title: PowerSploit
content: A collection of Microsoft PowerShell modules that can be used to aid penetration testers.

title: Empire
content: A post-exploitation framework that includes a pure-PowerShell Windows agent.

title: Responder
content: An LLMNR NBT-NS and MDNS poisoner with built-in rogue authentication servers.

title: Gitleaks
content: A tool for detecting secrets like passwords and API keys in git repos.

title: TruffleHog
content: A tool that searches through git repositories for high entropy strings and secrets.

title: Nikto
content: An open-source web server scanner which performs comprehensive tests.

title: Wfuzz
content: A tool designed for bruteforcing Web Applications.

title: Sqlmap
content: An open source penetration testing tool that automates the process of detecting and exploiting SQLi flaws.

title: Dirbuster
content: A multi threaded java application designed to brute force directories and files names.

title: Gobuster
content: A tool used to brute-force URIs and DNS subdomains.

title: Shodan
content: A search engine that lets the user find specific types of computers connected to the internet.

title: Censys
content: A search engine that enables researchers to discover the devices and networks that compose the Internet.

title: VirusTotal
content: A website that provides free checking of files for viruses.

title: Exploit-DB
content: An archive of exploits and vulnerable software.

title: Mitre ATT&CK
content: A globally-accessible knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques.

title: CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures)
content: A list of publicly disclosed computer security flaws.

title: CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System)
content: A free and open industry standard for assessing the severity of security vulnerabilities.

title: OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project)
content: An online community that produces articles and tools in the field of web application security.

title: SANS Institute
content: A private US for-profit company that specializes in information security and cybersecurity training.

title: Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP)
content: An independent information security certification.

title: Offensive Security Certified Professional (OSCP)
content: An ethical hacking certification offered by Offensive Security.

title: Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH)
content: A qualification obtained by demonstrating knowledge of how to look for weaknesses in target systems.

title: Security+
content: A global certification that validates the baseline skills necessary to perform core security functions.

title: EnCase
content: A digital forensics product developed by Guidance Software.

title: FTK (Forensic Toolkit)
content: A computer forensics software made by AccessData.

title: Autopsy
content: A digital forensics platform and graphical interface to The Sleuth Kit.

title: Volatilty
content: An open-source memory forensics framework for incident response and malware analysis.

title: Cuckoo Sandbox
content: An open source automated malware analysis system.

title: Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA)
content: A security standard for users of computing devices equipped with wireless internet connections.

title: WPA2
content: A security method added to WPA to provide even stronger data protection.

title: WPA3
content: The latest generation of Wi-Fi security.

title: Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP)
content: A security algorithm for IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.

title: War-dialing
content: A technique to automatically scan a list of telephone numbers to find modems.

title: Social Engineering Toolkit (SET)
content: An open-source Python-driven tool aimed at penetration testing via social engineering.

title: PhishMe
content: A solution that provides phishing defense and security awareness training.

title: KnowBe4
content: A provider of security awareness training and simulated phishing platform.

title: Carbon Black
content: An endpoint security software company.

title: CrowdStrike
content: A cybersecurity technology company that provides endpoint security and threat intelligence.

title: FireEye
content: A cybersecurity company that provides hardware software and services to investigate cyber attacks.

title: Palo Alto Networks
content: A global cybersecurity leader known for its next-generation firewalls.

title: Fortinet
content: A company that develops and markets cybersecurity software and appliances.

title: Check Point
content: A provider of software and combined hardware and software products for IT security.

title: Splunk
content: A software platform to search analyze and visualize machine-generated data.

title: LogRhythm
content: A company that specializes in Security Information and Event Management (SIEM).

title: QRadar
content: An enterprise security information and event management product from IBM.

title: ArcSight
content: A cybersecurity product that provides big data security analytics and intelligence.

title: Tenable
content: A cybersecurity company known for its vulnerability scanner Nessus.

title: Qualys
content: A provider of cloud-based security and compliance solutions.

title: Rapid7
content: A provider of security data and analytics solutions.

title: Nessus
content: A proprietary comprehensive vulnerability scanner.

title: OpenVAS
content: A software framework of several services and tools offering vulnerability scanning and management.

title: Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE)
content: One of Nmap's most powerful and flexible features that allows users to write scripts.

title: Maltego
content: An open source intelligence and forensics application.

title: The Harvester
content: A tool for gathering subdomain names e-mail addresses and usernames.

title: Sherlock
content: A tool to find usernames across social networks.

title: Honeyd
content: A small daemon that creates virtual hosts on a network.

title: Canary Tokens
content: A simple way to tripwire your infrastructure and get notified of intrusions.

title: Zero Trust Edge
content: A security framework that combines Zero Trust principles with software-defined networking.

title: EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response)
content: Tools used to protect endpoints by monitoring for suspicious behavior in real-time.

title: XDR (Extended Detection and Response)
content: A cross-platform approach to security that integrates data from endpoints networks and cloud.

title: SOAR
content: Security Orchestration Automation and Response tools that help teams streamline incident handling.

title: SIEM
content: Security Information and Event Management systems that provide real-time analysis of security alerts.

title: UEBA
content: User and Entity Behavior Analytics which looks for anomalies in user patterns to find threats.

title: Bluejacking
content: The practice of sending unsolicited messages to Bluetooth-enabled devices.

title: Bluesnarfing
content: The theft of information from a wireless device through a Bluetooth connection.

title: Vishing
content: Voice phishing where attackers use phone calls to trick victims into giving data.

title: Smishing
content: Phishing attempts delivered specifically through SMS or text messages.

title: Quishing
content: A phishing attack where a malicious link is embedded in a QR code.

title: Spear Phishing
content: A highly targeted phishing attack aimed at a specific individual or organization.

title: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
content: Scams where attackers impersonate executives to authorize fraudulent wire transfers.

title: Identity Provider (IdP)
content: A service that stores and manages digital identities for user authentication.

title: Privileged Access Management (PAM)
content: Tools and policies designed to secure and monitor high-level administrative accounts.

title: Bastion Host
content: A hardened server used to access a private network from an external network.

title: Jump Server
content: A controlled computer that manages access to devices in different security zones.

title: Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
content: A subnetwork that exposes an organization's external services to the untrusted internet.

title: Air Gap
content: A security measure that ensures a network is physically isolated from the internet.

title: Steganography
content: The art of hiding secret information within a non-secret file such as an image.

title: Polymorphic Code
content: Code that uses a mutation engine to change its appearance while keeping the same function.

title: Metamorphic Code
content: Code that rewrites itself entirely to evade signature-based detection.

title: Rootkit
content: Malware that grants an attacker persistent administrative access while remaining hidden.

title: Logic Bomb
content: Malicious code that executes only when certain logical conditions are met.

title: Worm
content: Self-replicating malware that spreads across networks without human interaction.

title: Trojan
content: Malware disguised as legitimate software to trick users into installing it.

title: Spyware
content: Software designed to gather data about a user and send it to a third party.

title: Adware
content: Malware that forces unwanted advertisements onto a user's screen.

title: Keylogger
content: Software or hardware that records every keystroke made on a device.

title: Crypto-jacking
content: The unauthorized use of a person's computer to mine cryptocurrency.

title: Formjacking
content: The use of malicious JavaScript to steal credit card info from payment forms.

title: Clickjacking
content: A technique that tricks users into clicking something different from what they see.

title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
content: An attack that forces a logged-in user to perform actions they didn't intend.

title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
content: Attacking a server by forcing it to make requests to internal resources.

title: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)
content: A vulnerability where a user can access another user's data by changing an ID.

title: Broken Access Control
content: Failures that allow users to act outside of their intended permissions.

title: Buffer Overflow
content: Writing more data to a memory buffer than it can hold to overwrite adjacent memory.

title: Heap Spraying
content: A technique to facilitate arbitrary code execution by saturating a program's memory.

title: SQL Map
content: An open-source tool that automates the detection and exploitation of SQL injection.

title: Burp Suite
content: An integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications.

title: Wireshark
content: A network protocol analyzer used to capture and inspect data packets.

title: Metasploit
content: A framework used by penetration testers to develop and execute exploit code.

title: Nmap
content: A network mapper used for discovery and security auditing of open ports.

title: BloodHound
content: A tool used to map complex attack paths within Active Directory environments.

title: Mimikatz
content: A tool used to extract passwords and hashes from Windows memory.

title: John the Ripper
content: A fast password-cracking tool used for security testing.

title: Hashcat
content: An advanced password recovery tool that utilizes GPU power.

title: Evil Twin
content: A rogue Wi-Fi access point that appears to be a legitimate network.

title: War Driving
content: The act of searching for Wi-Fi networks from a moving vehicle.

title: Blue Team
content: Defensive security professionals focused on maintaining system integrity.

title: Red Team
content: Offensive security experts who simulate real-world attacks.

title: Purple Team
content: A collaborative model where red and blue teams share insights to improve security.

title: White Hat
content: An ethical hacker who works within the law to find vulnerabilities.

title: Black Hat
content: A malicious hacker who exploits systems for personal gain.

title: Grey Hat
content: A hacker who finds vulnerabilities without permission but without malicious intent.

title: Script Kiddie
content: An amateur hacker who uses pre-made scripts without understanding how they work.

title: Hacktivist
content: A hacker who attacks systems for political or social causes.

title: Cyber Espionage
content: The use of cyberattacks to steal secrets from governments or corporations.

title: Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)
content: A prolonged and targeted cyberattack by a highly skilled actor.

title: Zero Day
content: A vulnerability that is exploited before the software vendor has a patch.

title: CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures)
content: A list of publicly disclosed cybersecurity flaws.

title: CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System)
content: A numerical score representing the severity of a vulnerability.

title: DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service)
content: Using multiple systems to flood a target's bandwidth or resources.

title: Botnet
content: A network of compromised computers controlled by a central attacker.

title: Honeypot
content: A decoy system designed to lure and study attackers.

title: Honeynet
content: A network of multiple honeypots to simulate a larger infrastructure.

title: Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
content: A system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity.

title: Intrusion Prevention System (IPS)
content: A system that detects and actively blocks malicious network traffic.

title: Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW)
content: A firewall that adds application-level inspection and threat intelligence.

title: Sandboxing
content: Running suspicious code in an isolated environment to observe its behavior.

title: Cryptography
content: The practice of securing communication through mathematical algorithms.

title: Symmetric Encryption
content: An encryption method that uses the same key for both locking and unlocking.

title: Asymmetric Encryption
content: Encryption that uses a public key to encrypt and a private key to decrypt.

title: Hashing
content: Converting data into a fixed-length string of characters that cannot be reversed.

title: Salt
content: Random data added to a password before hashing to prevent rainbow table attacks.

title: Digital Signature
content: A mathematical way to verify the authenticity and integrity of a message.

title: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
content: A system for managing digital certificates and public-private key pairs.

title: Certificate Authority (CA)
content: A trusted entity that issues digital certificates.

title: Transport Layer Security (TLS)
content: A protocol that provides secure communication over a computer network.

title: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
content: The predecessor to TLS used for securing web traffic.

title: Perfect Forward Secrecy
content: A feature that ensures session keys are not compromised even if the private key is.

title: Quantum Cryptography
content: Encryption methods based on the principles of quantum mechanics.

title: Post-Quantum Cryptography
content: Algorithms designed to be secure against attacks from quantum computers.

title: Secure Boot
content: A hardware feature that ensures a device boots using only trusted software.

title: TPM (Trusted Platform Module)
content: A dedicated chip on a motherboard used for cryptographic operations.

title: Hardening
content: The process of securing a system by reducing its surface of vulnerability.

title: Patch Management
content: The systematic process of updating software to fix security vulnerabilities.

title: Vulnerability Assessment
content: The process of identifying and prioritizing flaws in a system.

title: Penetration Test
content: A controlled attack on a system to find and exploit weaknesses.

title: Risk Assessment
content: The process of identifying and evaluating potential security threats.

title: Incident Response Plan
content: A set of instructions to help IT staff detect and recover from a breach.

title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP)
content: Tools that prevent sensitive data from leaving the corporate network.

title: Social Engineering
content: Manipulating people into giving up confidential information.

title: Tailgating
content: Following an authorized person into a secure physical area.

title: Dumpster Diving
content: Searching through trash to find sensitive documents or hardware.

title: Pretexting
content: Creating a fake scenario to trick a victim into sharing data.

title: Shadow IT
content: The use of IT systems or software without explicit organizational approval.

title: Supply Chain Attack
content: An attack that targets a third-party vendor to reach a larger organization.

title: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)
content: An attack where the actor intercepts communication between two parties.

title: Endpoint
content: Any device that connects to a network such as a laptop or smartphone.

title: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) Security
content: Scanning configuration files like Terraform or CloudFormation for security flaws.

title: Serverless Security
content: Protecting event-driven functions from injection and excessive permission risks.

title: Cloud Workload Protection Platform (CWPP)
content: Security tools specifically designed to protect VMs and containers in the cloud.

title: Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM)
content: Automated tools that identify misconfigurations and compliance risks in cloud environments.

title: Data Sovereignty
content: The concept that data is subject to the laws of the country where it is located.

title: Right to be Forgotten
content: A GDPR requirement allowing individuals to request the deletion of their personal data.

title: Privacy by Design
content: An approach that integrates data protection into the development of technologies.

title: Data Sanitization
content: The process of permanently erasing data from storage media so it cannot be recovered.

title: Degaussing
content: Using a high-powered magnet to disrupt a hard drive's magnetic field and destroy data.

title: Cryptographic Eradication
content: Destroying data by deleting the encryption keys used to protect it.

title: Chain of Custody
content: A chronological log showing who handled digital evidence during an investigation.

title: Write Blocker
content: A hardware device that prevents any data from being written to a suspect drive during forensics.

title: Slack Space
content: The unused space in a disk cluster that may contain hidden or deleted data.

title: RAM Forensics
content: Analyzing the volatile memory of a computer to find running processes or encryption keys.

title: Anti-Forensics
content: Techniques used by attackers to hide or delete evidence of their activity.

title: Indicator of Compromise (IoC)
content: Evidence such as a file hash or IP address that suggests a system was breached.

title: Indicator of Attack (IoA)
content: Focuses on the intent and behavior of an attacker rather than file-based evidence.

title: Traffic Pattern Analysis
content: Examining the volume and timing of network traffic to detect anomalies.

title: NetFlow
content: A protocol for collecting IP traffic information and monitoring network flow.

title: Packet Injection
content: The act of interfering with an established network connection by sending forged packets.

title: DNS Sinkhole
content: A DNS server that gives out false results to redirect traffic away from malicious domains.

title: Domain Fronting
content: A technique used to hide the true destination of traffic by using a different domain.

title: Fast-Flux DNS
content: A technique used by botnets to hide phishing sites behind a rapidly changing network of hosts.

title: Beaconing
content: The process of a compromised system checking in with a Command and Control server.

title: Lateral Movement
content: The process an attacker uses to move deeper into a network after an initial breach.

title: Pivot
content: Using a compromised system to attack or scan other systems in the same network.

title: Living off the Land (LotL)
content: Using legitimate system tools like PowerShell or WMI to carry out an attack.

title: Fileless Malware
content: Malware that operates entirely in memory to avoid detection by traditional antivirus.

title: Process Hollowing
content: Replacing the code of a legitimate process with malicious code in memory.

title: DLL Injection
content: Running malicious code in the address space of another process by loading a library.

title: API Hooking
content: Intercepting API calls to change or monitor the behavior of an application.

title: Exploit Mitigation
content: Technologies like ASLR and DEP that make it harder to exploit software bugs.

title: Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR)
content: Randomly arranging the positions of key data areas to prevent predictable attacks.

title: Data Execution Prevention (DEP)
content: A security feature that prevents code from running in non-executable memory regions.

title: Control Flow Guard (CFG)
content: A platform security feature that thwarts attacks that redirect code execution.

title: Sandbox Escape
content: The process of breaking out of a restricted virtual environment to access the host.

title: Side-Channel Attack
content: An attack based on physical information like power consumption or electromagnetic leaks.

title: Rowhammer
content: A hardware exploit where repeated access to a row of memory causes bits to flip.

title: Spectre
content: A hardware vulnerability that exploits speculative execution to leak sensitive data.

title: Meltdown
content: A vulnerability that allows a program to read the private memory of the operating system.

title: Microcode Update
content: A firmware-level patch used to fix hardware vulnerabilities like CPU bugs.

title: Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM)
content: The process of identifying risks throughout the lifecycle of a product or service.

title: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
content: A formal list of every component and library used in a piece of software.

title: Static Application Security Testing (SAST)
content: Analyzing source code for security flaws without executing the program.

title: Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST)
content: Testing a running application for vulnerabilities from the outside.

title: Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST)
content: Combining SAST and DAST to find vulnerabilities in real-time during use.

title: Web Application Firewall (WAF)
content: A firewall specifically designed to filter and monitor HTTP traffic.

title: API Gateway
content: A management tool that sits between a client and a collection of backend services.

title: JSON Web Token (JWT)
content: A compact way of securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.

title: Credential Harvester
content: A website or tool designed to trick users into entering their login details.

title: Password Spraying
content: Attempting a single common password against many different user accounts.

title: Brute Force Recovery
content: Trying every possible combination to recover an encrypted file or password.

title: Dictionary Attack
content: Using a list of known words or common passwords to attempt a login.

title: Rainbow Table
content: A precomputed table used for reversing cryptographic hash functions.

title: Key Stretching
content: A technique used to make a weak password more secure by increasing its computation time.

title: Bcrypt
content: A password-hashing function designed to be slow and resistant to brute-force attacks.

title: Scrypt
content: A memory-hard password-hashing function designed to prevent hardware acceleration attacks.

title: Argon2
content: The winner of the Password Hashing Competition and the current industry standard.

title: Homomorphic Encryption
content: A form of encryption that allows computation to be performed on encrypted data.

title: Zero-Knowledge Proof
content: A method where one party proves they know a secret without revealing the secret itself.

title: Diffie-Hellman
content: A method of securely exchanging cryptographic keys over a public channel.

title: Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC)
content: A powerful public-key cryptography approach based on elliptic curves.

title: Ephemeral Key
content: A temporary cryptographic key used for only one session.

title: Key Escrow
content: An arrangement where a third party holds a copy of a cryptographic key.

title: Hardware Security Module (HSM)
content: A physical device that manages digital keys and provides cryptographic processing.

title: Secure Element (SE)
content: A tamper-resistant chip capable of securely hosting applications and storing data.

title: Out-of-Band Authentication
content: Using a separate communication channel to verify a user's identity.

title: Push-Based Authentication
content: A login method where a notification is sent to a mobile app for approval.

title: Behavioral Biometrics
content: Identifying a person based on how they interact with a device like typing speed.

title: False Acceptance Rate (FAR)
content: The likelihood that a biometric system will incorrectly identify an unauthorized user.

title: False Rejection Rate (FRR)
content: The likelihood that a biometric system will fail to identify an authorized user.

title: Crossover Error Rate (CER)
content: The point where FAR and FRR are equal used to measure biometric accuracy.

title: Least Privilege
content: The principle of granting users only the minimum access needed for their job.

title: Separation of Duties
content: Dividing a task into multiple steps to prevent any one person from having total control.

title: Mandatory Access Control (MAC)
content: An access policy where the system determines who can access what based on labels.

title: Discretionary Access Control (DAC)
content: An access policy where the owner of a file decides who can access it.

title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
content: Granting permissions based on a user's role within an organization.

title: Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)
content: Granting access based on attributes like user location or time of day.

title: Directory Service
content: A database that stores and organizes information about users and network resources.

title: Active Directory (AD)
content: A Microsoft service used to manage users and computers in a Windows network.

title: LDAP
content: The Lightweight Directory Access Protocol used to search and manage directory services.

title: Kerberos
content: A network authentication protocol that uses tickets to allow nodes to communicate securely.

title: Single Sign-On (SSO)
content: An authentication process that allows a user to log in once for multiple systems.

title: Federated Identity
content: A system that allows a user to use the same credentials across different organizations.

title: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)
content: An XML-based standard for exchanging authentication data.

title: OAuth 2.0
content: A framework that allows applications to gain limited access to user accounts.

title: OpenID Connect
content: An identity layer on top of OAuth 2.0 that provides user profile information.

title: Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
content: A plan to maintain business operations during and after a disaster.

title: Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP)
content: A plan focused on restoring the IT infrastructure after a major failure.

title: Recovery Point Objective (RPO)
content: The maximum amount of data loss an organization is willing to accept.

title: Recovery Time Objective (RTO)
content: The maximum amount of time a system can be down after a failure.

title: Hot Site
content: A fully equipped data center that can take over operations immediately.

title: Cold Site
content: A backup site that has power and space but no pre-installed computer equipment.

title: Warm Site
content: A backup site that has some equipment but requires setup before it is functional.

title: Full Backup
content: A complete copy of all selected data.

title: Incremental Backup
content: Backing up only the data that has changed since the last backup of any kind.

title: Differential Backup
content: Backing up only the data that has changed since the last full backup.

title: Offsite Storage
content: Storing backup media in a separate physical location for safety.

title: Geofencing
content: Using GPS or RFID to define a virtual geographic boundary for security alerts.
